briefOverview: Joseph Smith urges the Saints to document and publicize the persecutions they suffered, treating this as a sacred duty tied to future vindication and divine deliverance.
summary: The Saints are told to gather detailed records of abuses, losses, and the names of perpetrators, along with libelous publications, so these can be presented to the world and governmental leaders. This comprehensive effort is framed as an imperative duty owed to God, angels, their families, widows, orphans, and the pure in heart who may be kept from truth by deception. The text denounces the oppressive spirit that has entrenched inherited falsehoods and caused widespread corruption. Believers are charged to bring hidden works of darkness to light and to take these tasks seriously, even if they seem small, because much in the future depends on them. Using the image of a large ship steered by a small helm, the Saints are encouraged to cheerfully do all in their power and then stand still to witness God’s salvation.
externalContext: This section comes from a March 1839 letter written by Joseph Smith and other Church leaders while imprisoned in Liberty Jail, Missouri, following the 1838 conflict between Latter-day Saints and Missouri residents. In October 1838, Missouri Governor Lilburn W. Boggs issued an Executive Order resulting in the expulsion of the Saints from the state. The letter (portions canonized as Doctrine and Covenants 121–123) addresses both theological consolation and practical steps for seeking redress. In the months and years following, Church members compiled affidavits and petitions for state and federal authorities as part of their legal and public efforts to obtain justice.
externalReferences: The imagery of a ship guided by a small helm echoes James 3:4, emphasizing how small instruments can direct great outcomes. The charge to “bring to light the hidden things of darkness” aligns with 1 Corinthians 4:5 (and see Ephesians 5:11–13), underscoring exposure of wrongdoing to the light. The description of people “lying in wait to deceive” closely parallels Ephesians 4:14. The call to act diligently and then “stand still” to see divine deliverance recalls Exodus 14:13–14; compare also prior Latter-day Saint counsel to seek lawful redress and act in good causes (Doctrine and Covenants 98:4–11; 58:26–28).

sectionTitles.title: Bring to Light; Act and Trust God

practicalQuestions: What specific injustices in my community should be documented, and how can I do so responsibly and truthfully?
How can I pair civic action (legal, governmental, public) with faith in God without neglecting either?
Whom do I know—especially widows, the fatherless, or the marginalized—who needs advocacy and support?
What “small” actions could steer larger outcomes toward justice and healing?
How can I communicate truth to those who “know not where to find it” with clarity and charity?
uncertainAreas: Verse 6’s reference to “that promise which shall call him forth from his hiding place” is not explicitly defined here; the precise promise and timing are unclear. The identity and scope of the “spirit” that has riveted inherited creeds upon the hearts of children (v. 7) is also not specified. The exact procedural steps or governmental bodies intended for redress are not detailed beyond a general appeal to the “heads of government.”
